cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: When following another vehicle as a beginning rider, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain a minimum four-second following distance.
questions.answerB: Get as close to the other vehicle as possible.
questions.answerC: Never be concerned about your following distance.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the left portion of the lane so the driver can easily see you.
questions.explanation: A following distance of at least four seconds is recommended for beginning riders. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Which type of sign is yellow with black lettering or symbols?
questions.answerB: Service
questions.answerC: Regulatory
questions.answerD: Speed limit
questions.explanation: Warning signs are yellow with black lettering or symbols and provide important information to motorists about upcoming road conditions.

questions.question: If attempting to brake in a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake more gradually than you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as you would on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Wait until you are not in the curve to brake.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Because tires have less traction when a motorcycle is leaning than when it is upright, always try to position your motorcycle in an upright position before braking. If you must brake while in a curve, apply the brakes more smoothly and gradually than if your motorcycle was traveling on a straightaway.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If carrying a load in a sidecar, the motorcycle's stopping distance:
questions.answerB: May be decreased.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern.
questions.answerD: Will be similar to the stopping distance of a two-wheeled motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Because adding a load to a motorcycle increases its weight, the vehicle's inertia may increase, causing its stopping distance to increase. Begin slowing and stopping earlier when riding a motorcycle with a load or passenger in its sidecar.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors, you should focus on:
questions.answerA: The road behind and to the side of your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Your arms.
questions.answerC: The road in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: The side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but itâ€™s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: Studies show that nearly ______ of riders killed in motorcycle crashes had been drinking.
questions.answerB: 40 percent
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.answerD: 80 percent
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a major contributor to motorcycle crashes, particularly fatal crashes. Studies show that nearly 40 percent of all riders killed in motorcycle accidents had been drinking.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerB: Drinking coffee.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerB: Faster than other vehicles.
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: When being passed, you should not move to the portion of the lane farthest from the passing driver because it:
questions.answerA: Discourages the passing driver from cutting into your lane too early.
questions.answerB: Encourages the passing driver to cut into your lane too early.
questions.answerC: Encourages the passing driver to complete the pass as quickly as possible.
questions.answerD: Encourages other drivers to pass you.
questions.explanation: Moving into the portion of your lane farthest from a passing vehicle is potentially dangerous because it could encourage the driver to return to your lane before it is safe to do so. It is safest to stay in the center of a lane when being passed.

questions.question: Which of the following does not offer protection to a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerB: Boots that go over the ankle
questions.answerC: A baseball cap that fits snugly
questions.answerD: Gloves
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid traffic signals.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: A motorcyclist's cushion of space:
questions.answerB: Should vary according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not necessary in most situations.
questions.answerD: Should be avoided to keep traffic moving safely.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up your following distance.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle could accelerate too quickly.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: Which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.answerB: The fasteners
questions.answerC: The tires
questions.answerD: The paint
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should check your motorcycle's tires, controls, chains, sprockets, shock absorbers, fasteners, and brakes. A small mechanical issue on a motorcycle can be extremely dangerous in traffic.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: A rectangular sign may be a:
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.answerD: Speed limit sign.
questions.explanation: Signs informing road users of road regulations, such as speed limits, are normally rectangular and colored white with black lettering or symbols. Riders must follow the rules posted on these regulatory signs.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way for a rider to increase their visibility?
questions.answerB: Using their headlight at all times
questions.answerC: Using their turn signals
questions.answerD: Waving at other drivers
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to other road users, you should wear brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials, use your headlight at all times, and use your signals and brake light properly.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Not be worn.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Brightly-colored and/or reflective clothing will increase your chances of being seen under any conditions. Remember that most motorcycle crashes happen in broad daylight so it is still best to wear bright clothing during the day.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: If a tailgater is following you too closely, it is advisable to flash your brake light before you begin to decelerate. The tailgater may be concentrating on you and may not be aware of hazards farther down the road that you are slowing to avoid.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: To increase your line of sight when preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Try to stand up on your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This will increase your line of sight and make you more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Slippery surfaces can make it difficult to control a motorcycle. Which of the following would be considered a slippery surface?
questions.answerB: A driveway
questions.answerC: Dry pavement
questions.answerD: A parking lot
questions.explanation: Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be slippery surfaces. Motorcyclists should ride with extra caution when riding over slippery surfaces.

questions.question: The proper footwear for riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Has short heels.
questions.answerC: Has tall heels.
questions.answerD: Is always sneakers.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should wear sturdy footwear that is high enough to cover and support your ankles. Short-heeled footwear is best because taller heels may catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so that they can't be caught on anything.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerB: When stopped at an intersection
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: When riding a three-wheeled motorcycle through a curve, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay on the outside of the lane.
questions.answerC: Change your path as needed.
questions.answerD: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle. The best path for a three-wheeler to take through a curve may not actually follow the curve. For example, you may need to move from the outside of the curve to the inside of the curve before straightening out your path.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, make sure it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Designed to meet U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: Snug.
questions.answerC: Defect-free.
questions.answerD: Attractive.
questions.explanation: You should select a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation and state standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: If your front tire locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the brake engaged until you come to a full stop.
questions.answerB: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.answerC: Release the brake lever and use only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release the brake lever until the tire regains traction.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the brake lever until the tire regains traction and re-apply the brake.

questions.question: When selecting footwear, you should choose:
questions.answerB: Shoes with long laces that cannot be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Shoes that cover your ankles.
questions.answerD: Shoes that are made from flimsy materials.
questions.explanation: When riding, wear boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Heels should be short so they don't catch on rough surfaces. Laces should be tucked in so they can't catch onto the moving parts of the motorcycle.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks that are parallel to the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerB: Avoid crossing the tracks for any reason.
questions.answerC: Try to cross the tracks at a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerD: Slowly inch across the tracks.
questions.explanation: To safely cross railroad tracks, trolley tracks, or pavement seams running parallel to your lane, move to a lane position that will allow you to cross them at an angle of at least 45 degrees. Then, make a quick, sharp turn. If you try to edge across, the tracks or seam could catch your tires and throw you off balance.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked cars to your right when there is no oncoming traffic to your left, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay toward the right side of your lane.
questions.answerB: Stay toward the left side of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look to your left frequently.
questions.answerD: Use your rearview mirrors more frequently than usual.
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is generally best to stay on the side of your lane that is not directly next to the cars. This will help to protect you from potential hazards like car doors being opened or people stepping out from between the cars. If there is traffic coming from the opposite direction, it is a good idea to stay in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerB: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake on slippery surfaces, such as wet pavement.
questions.answerD: Only use the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes every time you slow or stop, regardless of the condition of the road.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Equip and adjust your motorcycle to carry the passenger.
questions.answerB: Ride as you would without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Ensure that footrests are available for only you, the operator.
questions.answerD: Instruct the passenger after you begin your trip.
questions.explanation: You should transport a passenger only if your motorcycle is appropriately equipped and adjusted to do so. Among other things, your motorcycle should have separate footrests for the passenger and a seat that is large enough for more than one person to sit comfortably. You may need to adjust your headlight, tire pressure, and suspension to accommodate the extra weight of a passenger.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Allow you to blend in with traffic.
questions.answerB: Provide an escape route.
questions.answerC: Encourage others to use your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When riding in a group, you should:
questions.answerB: Place inexperienced riders at the back of the group.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Not tailgate other riders within the group.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, it is generally best to use a staggered formation. Use your mirrors periodically to check on riders behind you. Both the lead and sweep riders should be experienced motorcyclists who know group riding procedures well. Maintain proper space cushions within the group of riders.

questions.question: Convex mirrors make cars seem:
questions.answerB: Farther away.
questions.answerC: Faster.
questions.answerD: Narrower.
questions.explanation: Rounded, or convex, mirrors provide a wider view of the road than flat mirrors, but they also make objects seem farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: If hazards are on your left, you should ride:
questions.answerA: In the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: In the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: In any portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: On the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When hazards exist to your left, it is often best to ride in the right portion of the lane. Be prepared to adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto the seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the seat as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: Passengers should lean as the operator leans. A passenger should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerB: The rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Both front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Either the front or rear brake, but not both.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: Shifting into a lower gear causes an effect similar to:
questions.answerB: Accelerating.
questions.answerC: Swerving.
questions.answerD: Turning.
questions.explanation: Shifting your motorcycle into a lower gear causes an effect similar to applying the brakes. This is known as engine braking.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerB: Accelerate.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: Riding between two vehicles moving in the same direction:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged if traffic is heavy.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged during the day to prevent traffic jams.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable if the motorcyclist is comfortable with the move.
questions.explanation: In Oregon, it is illegal for motorcycles and mopeds to pass between two moving vehicles on a multilane highway or one-way street.

questions.question: In any crash, you have a better chance of avoiding serious injury if you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Wear face or eye protection.
questions.answerC: Wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Have a windshield.
questions.explanation: You can reduce your risk of injury when riding a motorcycle by wearing an approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: Where is the horn button usually located?
questions.answerB: By the right handgrip
questions.answerC: By the left footrest
questions.answerD: By the right footrest
questions.explanation: Make sure that you are aware of the locations of all your motorcycle's controls before beginning to ride. The horn button on a motorcycle is usually located next to the left handgrip.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: The front brake is more powerful than the rear brake.
questions.answerB: The rear brake is more powerful than the front brake.
questions.answerC: Both the front and rear brakes are equally powerful.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: To lower the chance of a crash, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to react to hazards.
questions.answerD: Hope another driver sees you.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you must ensure that you are visible to others on the road and that other drivers understand what you're planning to do. Clearly communicate your intentions through proper signaling and lane positioning. Maintain an adequate space cushion and scan your path of travel, identifying upcoming hazards and being prepared to react.

questions.question: If the chain or belt of your motorcycle breaks, you will:
questions.answerA: Experience a sudden increase in power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerB: Experience a sudden loss of power to the rear wheel.
questions.answerC: Experience a sudden loss of power to the front wheel.
questions.answerD: Experience a sudden increase in power to the front wheel.
questions.explanation: If your drive chain or belt fails, you will experience an immediate loss of power to the rear wheel.

questions.question: How is the accelerator controlled?
questions.answerB: With the left hand
questions.answerC: With the right foot
questions.answerD: With the left foot
questions.explanation: The accelerator of a motorcycle is located by the right handgrip and is controlled with the right hand.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: If you find yourself riding alongside another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver.
questions.answerC: Stay alongside the vehicle until the next exit and then exit.
questions.answerD: Let the other driver worry about it.
questions.explanation: Riding directly next to another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if another hazard arises. If you find yourself riding directly alongside another vehicle, either speed up or drop back.

questions.question: Where is the clutch lever usually located?
questions.answerB: On the right handgrip
questions.answerC: Near the left footrest
questions.answerD: Near the right footrest
questions.explanation: The clutch lever of a motorcycle is usually located on the left handgrip.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Requires little traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: Which types of brakes do most motorcycles have?
questions.answerB: Rear and emergency
questions.answerC: Front and rear
questions.answerD: Only a front brake
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have one brake for each wheel. The front brake carries more braking power than the rear brake.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: Taking a turn too fast:
questions.answerA: Is acceptable as long as you stay under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Is safer on a motorcycle than in a car.
questions.answerC: Is acceptable as long as no vehicles are near you.
questions.answerD: Can cause you to end up in another lane or leave the road.
questions.explanation: Taking a turn too fast is dangerous. If you cannot hold the turn, you may end up turning into another lane or even off of the road entirely. Use caution when taking a turn.

questions.question: When a group of riders is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should:
questions.answerB: Pass in a staggered formation with several riders passing at the same time.
questions.answerC: Pass one at a time.
questions.answerD: Avoid passing.
questions.explanation: When a group of motorcyclists is passing another vehicle on a two-lane road, the riders should pass the vehicle one at a time. Each motorcyclist should complete their pass before the next rider's pass begins.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because they will distract you.
questions.answerC: Should be avoided since other drivers will see you easily.
questions.answerD: Are only recommended in bad weather.
questions.explanation: For your safety, it is important to be aware of what's behind you. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal searching routine.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while riding and you must stop, it is usually best to:
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires fails, hold the handgrips firmly and begin to slow down by easing off the throttle while maintaining a straight course. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is still good, if you are sure of which tire that is. Edge toward the side of the road as you slow down, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: If your motorcycle is being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerB: Ride alongside the dog.
questions.answerC: Stop until the dog loses interest.
questions.answerD: Approach the dog slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind. If you encounter a larger animal, brake and prepare to stop.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: If only one alcoholic drink is consumed:
questions.answerA: Judgment and riding abilities can still be affected.
questions.answerB: There is usually no effect on the body.
questions.answerC: There is an effect on the body, but it only lasts for a short time.
questions.answerD: There is an effect on the body, but it can be eliminated by drinking coffee.
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can significantly affect the skills that are needed for safe riding. The only way to remove the alcohol content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it.

questions.question: Most motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Have only a rear brake.
questions.answerC: Have brakes in both the front and rear.
questions.answerD: Have three brakes: one in the front, one in the rear, and an emergency brake.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles generally have two brakes, one for the front wheel and one for the rear wheel.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerB: Keep the motorcycle from leaning.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerB: Not be worn during the day
questions.answerC: Never be worn.
questions.answerD: Not be worn at night.
questions.explanation: Wear reflective materials to increase your visibility, especially when riding at night. Brightly-colored clothing with reflective materials will make you more visible to other road users.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic?
questions.answerB: Highways
questions.answerC: Parking lots
questions.answerD: Residential areas
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between your motorcycle and other traffic is at intersections. Be extra alert when riding somewhere where another vehicle may cross in front of your path of travel.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: Your primary source for information about your motorcycle should be:
questions.answerB: A book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: A former owner.
questions.answerD: Someone knowledgeable about motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Your owner's manual should be your primary source for information about your specific motorcycle. Your manual will include information about the motorcycle's specifications, operation, and suggested maintenance.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: Long-term exposure to wind noise:
questions.answerB: Can cause hearing loss.
questions.answerC: Is not harmful.
questions.answerD: Is less damaging than listening to music.
questions.explanation: Long-term exposure to wind noise while riding can cause hearing damage, even if you wear a helmet. Use of proper hearing protection is recommended to prevent damage.

questions.question: Most crashes occur in broad daylight. To be more visible, you should:
questions.answerB: Wear darkly-clothing.
questions.answerC: Ride without your headlight.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: Because most crashes happen in broad daylight, you should always wear brightly-colored clothing while riding, even during the day.

questions.question: The clothing you wear while riding should protect you from all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Windburn.
questions.answerC: Chapped lips.
questions.answerD: Dehydration.
questions.explanation: The clothes you wear when riding a motorcycle should protect you from sunburn, windburn, rain, dehydration, cold, and parts of the motorcycle. Your clothing should provide you with additional protection in the case of a crash.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, clothing:
questions.answerA: Should be loose enough to flap in the wind.
questions.answerB: Should not cover your arms or legs completely.
questions.answerC: Should not include a jacket if the weather is warm.
questions.answerD: Can provide protection in the event of a crash.
questions.explanation: The right clothing can provide vital protection if you are involved in a collision. Always wear a jacket and pants that fully cover your arms and legs, even in warm weather. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but should also be loose enough that your movement is not restricted.

questions.question: During your pre-ride inspection, you should check all of the following, except the:
questions.answerB: Headlight and taillight.
questions.answerC: Turn signals.
questions.answerD: Reflectors.
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: When it starts raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Avoid riding down the center of a lane under wet conditions. Instead, ride in the tire tracks left by the cars ahead of you. The left tire track will often be best, but this can vary depending on traffic and other conditions.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerB: Restricts the field of vision.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: A proper lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Allow you to set up for turns.
questions.answerB: Allow an escape route.
questions.answerC: Allow you to avoid wind blasts from other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Allow you to be in another vehicleâ€™s blind spot.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If riding a three-wheel motorcycle in a group, you should travel in a:
questions.answerB: Pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: Single-file line.
questions.answerD: Row of pairs.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best for a group of two-wheeled motorcycles, three-wheeled motorcycles are too wide to allow this formation. A group of riders on three-wheeled motorcycles should travel in a single-file line.

questions.question: When riding, goggles:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face, but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Are not as effective at protecting your eyes as eyeglasses.
questions.answerD: Are not effective in providing any protection.
questions.explanation: Goggles can provide protection for your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face. Eyeglasses are not an adequate substitute for either goggles or a face shield.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerB: Should hang loose.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: A good leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Hold onto their seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the bike as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto the operator.
questions.explanation: Passengers should sit directly behind the operator and lean as the operator leans. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator, holding onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: An integrated braking system:
questions.answerA: Applies partial rear braking when the front brake is applied.
questions.answerB: Applies partial front braking when the rear brake is applied.
questions.answerC: Applies even braking for both the front and rear brakes when either is applied.
questions.answerD: Learns and remembers the approximate braking force used by the rider.
questions.explanation: An integrated braking system is a variant of a linked braking system. Partial front braking is applied whenever the rear brake is activated. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: You should maintain an increased following distance:
questions.answerB: If traffic is light.
questions.answerC: If you can see through the vehicles in front of you to determine traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum four-second following distance.

questions.question: When both braking and swerving must be done to avoid an unexpected hazard, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Perform one action, then the other.
questions.answerB: Perform both actions at the same time and apply extra braking pressure.
questions.answerC: Perform both actions at the same time, but mainly focus on swerving.
questions.answerD: Not perform either action.
questions.explanation: Because you need adequate traction to swerve safely, you should not brake and swerve at the same time. Instead, if you approach a hazard that requires you to brake and swerve, you should perform one action and then the other.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: Usually, a good way to handle a tailgater is to:
questions.answerA: Move onto the shoulder to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Speed up and put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerC: Ignore them.
questions.answerD: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.explanation: Usually, the best way to handle a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to follow you at a faster speed.

questions.question: When traveling on a motorcycle with a sidecar, the passenger should ride:
questions.answerB: In the sidecar.
questions.answerC: Either on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.answerD: Neither on the motorcycle or in the sidecar.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle has a sidecar, it is best for your passenger to ride in the sidecar. They should keep their hands inside the sidecar at all times.

questions.question: If a friend has had too much to drink and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take roads that are not crowded.
questions.answerC: Not get involved.
questions.answerD: Take their keys.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding, including taking their keys, if necessary. Arrange an alternative way for them to get home.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Happen at night.
questions.answerC: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have ridden their motorcycles for less than six months.
questions.explanation: Always take extra care when riding a new or unfamiliar motorcycle. Most crashes involve riders who have had less than six months of experience with the motorcycle that they are using.

questions.question: A group of riders should pass another vehicle:
questions.answerB: In a pyramid formation.
questions.answerC: One at a time.
questions.answerD: In a splintered formation.
questions.explanation: On a two-lane highway, a group of riders should pass another vehicle one at a time. The second rider should not begin to pass until the first rider has safely re-entered the original lane. Riders should continue in this pattern until they have all safely passed the vehicle.

questions.question: During the day, your headlight should:
questions.answerB: Be used on its high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Be used on its low beam setting.
questions.answerD: Alternate between high beam and low beam settings.
questions.explanation: Using your high beam headlight during the day increases the likelihood that other drivers will see you. Use your high beam headlight any time you are not riding behind or approaching other vehicles.

questions.question: If using a sidecar to transport a load, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow the load to move freely.
questions.answerB: Secure the load so its weight does not shift.
questions.answerC: Place the load unsecured in the seat.
questions.answerD: Secure the load near the front of the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Loads carried in a sidecar should be secured so that they do not shift and affect the motorcycle's handling. Loads should be distributed toward the rear of the sidecar to reduce tipping of the nose of the sidecar in the event of a sudden left turn.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerB: Only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Both brakes.
questions.answerD: Either brake, but never both at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always simultaneously use both brakes to stop. The brakes are most effective when used at the same time.

questions.question: When riding at night:
questions.answerA: Distances are easier to judge than they are during the day.
questions.answerB: Using a high beam headlight always makes it difficult to see.
questions.answerC: Use only one lane position.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: When riding at night, you should reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use your high beam headlight whenever you are riding where there is no other traffic. Always be prepared to adjust your lane position to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: If you wait an hour per alcoholic drink before you ride your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: To make a quick stop on wet pavement, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.explanation: Use both brakes if you must make a quick stop on a slippery surface. The front brake is safe to use on a slippery surface if applied gradually to prevent locking.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer in a weaving pattern.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerB: You will be slowing down suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals do not work.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle's single brake light is not as noticeable as the two larger brake lights of a car or truck. It can be a good idea to flash your brake light to help others notice it, especially when you need to slow down more quickly than surrounding drivers may expect.

questions.question: If you are preparing to pass another operator on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Get into the right part of the lane so you can be seen in their side mirror.
questions.answerB: Get into the left part of the lane to increase your line of sight.
questions.answerC: Stay in the center part of the lane so you can be seen in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Weave in your lane to draw attention to yourself.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on its left, ride in the left portion of your lane to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to any drivers in the passing lane. Use your mirrors and turn your head to check for traffic before changing lanes.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerC: Push their bike over.
questions.answerD: Encourage friends to talk them out of riding.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding. It can be helpful to recruit a group of friends to intervene and apply peer pressure to the person.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn your handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: When adjusting your rearview mirror, be sure you can:
questions.answerA: See the lane behind you and the lane next to you.
questions.answerB: See only the lane behind you.
questions.answerC: See only the lane next to you.
questions.answerD: See most of your helmet.
questions.explanation: Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you. When properly adjusted, a mirror may show the edge of your arm or shoulder, but itâ€™s the road behind you and to the side of you that is most important.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerB: Will never happen.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.answerD: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: In potential high-risk areas, such as near intersections, shopping areas, school zones, and construction zones, cover the clutch and both brakes to reduce the time you will need to react to potential hazards.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing downward, it means the operator plans to slow down or stop.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: You should use a larger cushion of space:
questions.answerB: When it is sunny outside.
questions.answerC: When it is colder than usual.
questions.answerD: When you are following other motorcycles.
questions.explanation: A two-second following distance is generally appropriate. Allow a larger cushion of space when riding under conditions that will increase your stopping distance, such as when the road surface is icy or wet.

questions.question: Smoothly downshifting on motorcycles:
questions.answerB: Can allow the rider to engine brake.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if other vehicles are around.
questions.explanation: Engine braking by smoothly downshifting can be a useful option for motorcyclists. If you choose to engine brake, apply your brake lights separately to let other drivers know that you are slowing down.

questions.question: As a motorcycle operator, you can help others see you by:
questions.answerB: Wearing bright clothing.
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerD: Not using turn signals.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen, wear brightly-colored clothing, use your headlight at all times, and use your turn signals.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Tread.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: Riding alongside a car:
questions.answerB: Can place you in a blind spot.
questions.answerC: Is not an issue unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Can make driving easier for the other motorist.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because it may place you in the driver's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle will block your path of escape.

questions.question: ____ can remove alcohol and its effects from your body.
questions.answerB: Coffee
questions.answerC: Exercise
questions.answerD: Fresh air
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is not drinking alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, fresh air, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: The center portion of a traffic lane is where:
questions.answerA: Debris and oil drippings from cars often collect.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle riders should always travel for safety.
questions.answerC: Most accidents happen.
questions.answerD: Drivers are least likely to see a motorcyclist.
questions.explanation: The centermost portion of a lane is where debris and oil drippings from cars often collect. Other hazards, such as utility hole covers, can also be found in the centermost portion of the lane.

questions.question: A passenger must wear a helmet if:
questions.answerA: They are under 25 years of age.
questions.answerB: There is a lot of traffic on the road.
questions.answerC: The operator is required by law to wear a helmet.
questions.answerD: They do not have a motorcycle license.
questions.explanation: Any motorcycle operator or passenger under the age of 18 must wear a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards. If the operator is required to wear a helmet, then any passenger must also wear a helmet, regardless of age. It is recommended that all riders wear helmets during every ride.

questions.question: The gear shift lever is located:
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest.
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest.
questions.answerC: Behind the left footrest.
questions.answerD: Behind the right footrest.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the left foot. To shift up to a higher gear, position your foot under the shift lever and lift. To downshift, press the shift lever down.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerC: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerD: Use your high beam light, if possible.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. Use your high beam headlight, except when following or meeting another vehicle.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerB: Rider more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: Start slowing later than usual.
questions.answerD: Try to squeeze into smaller gaps in traffic.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a passenger will affect the handling of your motorcycle. Expect your motorcycle to accelerate more slowly than usual, turn more slowly than usual, and require extra space to come to a complete stop. Ride more slowly, start slowing sooner when approaching a stop, open up a larger space cushion, and wait for larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging into traffic.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, motorcycle riders should turn their heads to look over their shoulders because:
questions.answerA: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They can catch the attention of other drivers by turning their heads.
questions.answerC: Mirrors are not really helpful.
questions.answerD: They should try to make eye contact with surrounding drivers.
questions.explanation: Like any other vehicle, a motorcycle has blind spots that cannot be seen by a rider using their mirrors. A motorcyclist should always turn their head to check for vehicles or other hazards in their blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerB: The ownerâ€™s manual.
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Travel on the shoulder so you are not next to other traffic.
questions.explanation: To ride safely on a slippery surface, you should use both brakes when braking is necessary, reduce your speed, and avoid making sudden moves. Be especially alert to oily areas, shaded areas, dirt, gravel, and bridges, as these surfaces may provide less traction than others.

questions.question: Goggles will:
questions.answerB: Be an equally as effective as a face shield.
questions.answerC: Offer the same protection as a windshield.
questions.answerD: Provide protection for your entire face.
questions.explanation: Wearing goggles provides protection for your eyes, but not for the rest of your face. A face shield provides protection for your whole face and is recommended above goggles. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: If your motorcycle has convex mirrors and you are not familiar with this type of mirror, you should practice using the mirrors because:
questions.answerA: Most people arenâ€™t used to using mirrors.
questions.answerB: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look farther away than they really are.
questions.answerC: Unlike flat mirrors, they make items look closer than they really are.
questions.answerD: It can be difficult to remember to look at mirrors while riding.
questions.explanation: In comparison to flat mirrors, convex mirrors provide a wider view of the road behind you. They also make objects seem farther away than they actually are. Take the time to get used to your mirrors if your motorcycle is equipped with convex mirrors.

questions.question: In the context of group riding, what does the hand signal pictured mean?
questions.answerB: Danger ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.answerD: Merge.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. If a lead rider extends their left arm straight down with their palm facing back, the group of riders should come to a stop.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, the operator should:
questions.answerB: Increase their speed.
questions.answerC: Deflate the tires to accommodate the extra weight.
questions.answerD: Not warn passengers of impending hazards.
questions.explanation: Because a motorcycle handles differently when under the weight of a passenger, an operator should maintain a larger space cushion when transporting another person.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look where you are going.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go by turning only your head. Keep your knees against the gas tank to help maintain your balance while turning. Your arms should be slightly bent any time you are holding the handgrips.

questions.question: When being passed, all of the following are potential hazards, except:
questions.answerB: Objects being thrown from other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blasts of wind.
questions.answerD: Headlights.
questions.explanation: When being passed, motorcyclists should be careful not to be hit by any part of the passing vehicle, including its mirrors. In addition to the vehicle itself, motorcyclists should be aware of wind gusts coming from the passing vehicle and potential objects being thrown by a passenger in the vehicle who may not be paying attention to the road.

questions.question: Where is the throttle usually located?
questions.answerB: Near the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handle grip
questions.answerD: On the right handle grip
questions.explanation: The throttle of a motorcycle is usually located on the right handle grip. Be sure to know where all of your motorcycle's controls are located before riding.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a position that will allow the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, you should position yourself so you can be seen in the other driver's rearview mirror. Riding in the center portion of the lane will generally ensure that you will appear in the middle of their rearview mirror, where the driver is most likely to notice you.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to blend into traffic and not be noticed by other drivers.
questions.answerB: Not use turn signals unless you are traveling at night.
questions.answerC: Use your turn signals when changing lanes and making turns.
questions.answerD: Ride closely to the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, ensure that you are visible to others on the road. Communicate your intentions through your turn signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain an adequate space cushion, scan your path of travel 12 seconds ahead of your vehicle, and be prepared to act if any hazards arise.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You must complete the pass without exceeding the speed limit.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone if the pass was started before the no passing zone began.
questions.answerC: You may exceed the speed limit.
questions.answerD: You should pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: All passes must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is permitted.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before.
questions.answerB: Not assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before and explain the process.
questions.answerC: Not let them ask questions.
questions.answerD: Not bother with explaining anything since they are only a passenger and not in control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle passenger needs to understand how to ensure a safe ride ride for both themselves and the operator. An operator should never assume the passenger already knows what to do. Give a passenger complete instructions before every ride.

questions.question: Common drugs, such as cold tablets:
questions.answerA: Can affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Usually wonâ€™t affect a rider's abilities to safely operate their motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Pose no risk to a rider's operating abilities.
questions.answerD: Are always acceptable to take before riding because they are sold over-the-counter.
questions.explanation: Almost all drugs, including over-the-counter medications, have the potential to impact the abilities you need to ride safely. Make sure you understand the side effects of any drug before combining it with riding.

questions.question: It is difficult for other motorists to see motorcycles at night. To make up for that, a motorcycle rider should:
questions.answerA: Reduce their speed when riding at night.
questions.answerB: Sound their horn repeatedly when riding at night.
questions.answerC: Not ride at night.
questions.answerD: Stay directly in front of another vehicle to be seen in their headlights when riding at night.
questions.explanation: Strategies for safely riding at night include reducing your speed, increasing your following distance, using the lights of the car ahead to help see farther down the road, using your high beam headlight (unless following or meeting another vehicle), and being flexible about your lane position.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely.
